awd_titl_txt: Understanding Mechanisms of Membrane Biofouling in Anaerobic Membrane Bioreactors Using Polymer Surface Dissection
awd_abstract_narration:
Anaerobic membrane bioreactors (AnMBRs) can be used as a low-energy approach to wastewater treatment to produce renewable energy and high-quality water for reuse. However, these bioreactors are limited by membrane fouling caused in part by the attachment of bacteria in wastewater that leads to formation of biofilms at the membrane surface. This fouling accounts for 50% of the AnMBR energy use. The goal of this project is to discover and characterize the key bacteria that initiate biofilm formation on AnMBR membrane surfaces, learn how these bacteria modify the membrane during the fouling process, and identify the physical characteristics of the membrane that make it prone to biofouling. The knowledge gained from these studies will inform the design of improved membranes and membrane treatment strategies that will progress AnMBRs toward economical and sustainable use in wastewater treatment facilities, agro-based industries, and confined animal feeding operations. The project will use the Kansas Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation and the Developing Scholars Program to recruit and retain minority students from rural community colleges in Kansas for summer and year-long internships at Kansas State University, preparing them for careers in sustainable environmental research and technology. If successful, this project will help advance water treatment technologies to protect the Nation's water supply and energy security.

The objective of this research is to discover microorganisms that initiate biofouling on membranes in anaerobic membrane bioreactors (AnMBRs) and to characterize their molecular fouling strategies. While much effort has focused on developing chemical and physical treatment methods to alleviate biofouling, a poor understanding of the fundamental mechanisms that drive biofilm formation limit long-term strategies to mitigate fouling over these membrane surfaces. The central hypothesis is that early-stage biofouling is driven by a sub-group of AnMBR community members that locally modify the membrane surface through secretion of exopolysaccharides and soluble microbial products. To test this hypothesis, the use of a novel, non-destructive method that uses biocompatible polymeric materials to remove live cells from the membrane surface, termed polymer surface dissection (PSD), will be investigated. The PSD method will enable precise sectioning of early colonizers from the membrane surface in a spatially controlled manner for cell cultivation and microbial identification. This will be coupled with physicochemical analyses of the corresponding fouling sites on the membrane surface using scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy. The PSD approach will be used to characterize fouling in a laboratory setting using synthetic wastewater. These findings will be compared with data from a pilot-scale AnMBR reactor system to understand the effect of realistic environmental variables on membrane biofouling. The knowledge gained from these studies will inform rational AnMBR operation and treatment strategies that inhibit specific organisms, and will lead to the development of improved anti-fouling membrane materials. Beyond these bench and pilot scale systems, the PSD method can also be used to uncover microbial assembly mechanisms in other wastewater treatment systems where biofouling is a limiting issue.

por.por_cntn:
Anaerobic membrane bioreactors (AnMBRs) are an emerging environmental biotechnology with potential for energy-positive wastewater treatment while providing nutrient recovery. However, feasible and economical AnMBR operation is critically limited by membrane fouling, which accounts for greater than 50% of all energy expenditures during operation. Reducing energy costs by mitigating membrane fouling is key for achieving sustainable and economic AnMBR operation. The goal of this project was to provide a fundamental, mechanistic understanding of biofilm formation on AnMBR membranes in order to reduce the impact of biofouling.

In support of this effort, the Polymer Surface Dissection (PSD) experimental method for isolating small biofilm aggregates from membrane surfaces for molecular analysis was successfully developed. The PSD method uses bio-functional, light-responsive hydrogels to detach microbes from a membrane surface. Patterned light is then used to retrieve cells captured in the hydrogel for DNA extraction and genomic sequencing. This method was demonstrated by correlating microbial composition with aggregate area during wastewater biofouling over polyvinylidene fluoride membranes. It was discovered that very small biofilms were highly diverse in composition, reflective of the composition of the overall wastewater community, while larger biofilms became enriched in specific types of bacteria (Proteobacteria). The PSD method provides insight into how young biofilms change in composition as they develop on wastewater membrane surfaces, and it is expected that this new experimental approach will be broadly useful to other researchers studying biofilm development in a variety of different systems.

In the later parts of the project, biofouling studies were extended to a lab scale AnMBR system (115 L reactor volume) with a novel side tube membrane module and a pilot scale AnMBR system (treatment capacity of 1000 gallons wastewater per day). The effect of extraction temperature on soluble microbial product (SMP) and extracellular polymeric substance (EPS) profiles for biological nutrient removal sludges and aerobic membrane bioreactor sludge were investigated. SMP and EPS are major components of the colloidal matter implicated in membrane biofouling. A general purpose extraction temperature of 60 C for SMP and EPS from wastewater sludge was identified. Fluorometry was also developed as an analytical method that provided semi-quantitative information on SMP and EPS constituents, particularly its proteinaceous components, serving as a dynamic and rapid tool to monitor and control biofouling. Fundamental studies on the lab-scale AnMBR revealed that the dominant membrane fouling mechanism when operating below the critical flux was pore constriction, driven by the deposition of soluble organic matter. Through long term pilot scale AnMBR studies, it was demonstrated that membrane biofouling was minimized by a decrease in colloidal material, measured by semi-soluble chemical oxygen demand (ssCOD), rather than bioreactor total solids concentration. This was further supported through the use of fluorometric measurements, which showed an increase in tyrosine-like compounds during heavy fouling conditions, suggesting that proteinaceous materials have a large influence on the membrane fouling process. These findings can advance membrane maintenance strategies in both AnMBRs and other membrane based processes for mainstream wastewater treatment and can greatly decrease the chemical and energy footprint of fouling control approaches.

The findings from this research have been disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations. A final manuscript detailing the findings from the latter part of this project is currently in preparation. A broader impact of the project was to provide educational and research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in chemical engineering and civil engineering and to disseminate the research project to the general public. The project provided extensive training for two Ph.D. students in chemical engineering and for two Ph.D. students in civil engineering. The project also provided research opportunities for multiple chemical engineering undergraduates, including students from underrepresented groups in STEM. Several graduate and undergraduate students involved in the project went on to start industry positions in water treatment after their graduation. Additionally, AnMBR design problems were used in senior design projects for chemical engineering undergraduate students over the course of two semesters. Finally, the research project was communicated to the public through a Science Cafe event (Manhattan, KS) sponsored by the Kansas Citizens for Science organization.
